topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Adam shares his core advice for marketing in changing economic conditions (assume PMF has shifted), and Lenny introduces the show and Adam’s background across Uber, Lambda School, and MasterClass.

topics.title: Improv experience and career phases
topics.summary: Adam describes his history with improv (Second City, ImprovOlympic), why he kept it as a hobby, and how it complements his professional life.

topics.title: Improv principles applied to business collaboration
topics.summary: They discuss how improv skills translate to work—especially “Yes, and…” and “gift of details”—and how these improve cross-functional collaboration and communication.

topics.title: Why teams should take improv classes
topics.summary: Adam recommends improv 101 as a practical way to build adaptability and openness, and suggests making collaboration behaviors explicit team goals with accountability.

topics.title: Framework for evaluating emerging acquisition channels
topics.summary: Adam outlines a three-part framework: (1) overlap of customer needs, company goals, and channel strengths; (2) channel DNA (maturity, risk, and monetization); (3) company DNA (risk tolerance and existing channel mix).

topics.title: How to test new channels effectively
topics.summary: They cover practical testing guidance: start small, define success signals upfront, avoid letting tests drag past a quarter, and look for directional momentum when measurement is imperfect.

topics.title: Promising channels: OTT, influencers, VR, podcasts
topics.summary: Adam shares which channels he finds most interesting now (OTT/streaming TV, influencer marketing, VR in limited cases, and podcasts—especially for B2B) and why each may or may not scale.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Mid-roll sponsor segment featuring Amplitude, discussing product analytics, experimentation, and CDP capabilities supporting the product loop.

topics.title: Emerging channel hit rate and influencer tools
topics.summary: Adam estimates truly new channels only work ~5% of the time, notes higher success with newly-scalable or newly-changed channels, and briefly mentions influencer tooling (e.g., Grin) while noting the workflow remains manual.

topics.title: Crossing the chasm and shifting product-market fit
topics.summary: They discuss how early adopters differ from mainstream users, why many teams mis-define TAM vs PMF, and Adam’s advice to reassess PMF during market/economic shifts rather than reflexively adding new channels.

topics.title: Defining the Growth CMO role
topics.summary: Adam explains why traditional CMOs often fail at product-led companies and defines a Growth CMO as tightly coupled with product, iterative in approach (even on brand), and oriented around compounding learning loops.

topics.title: Growth CMO attributes: data, agility, experimentation
topics.summary: Adam details key traits: data-driven measurement beyond direct response, agile iteration across the funnel (including brand), and broad experimentation; he also argues marketing and product are now inseparable in modern software companies.
